title: 106_hr942
content: The "Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act" is a new law that revises duopoly rules in the Communications Act of 1934. The Broadcast Ownership for the 21st Century Act revises duopoly rules by allowing ownership of two stations with overlapping coverage contours in separate television markets or two television stations within the same market, with at least one being a UHF station. Existing local marketing agreements between two stations in the same market are exempt from the duopoly rule, and in exceptional cases, ownership of two VHF stations may be permitted. The Commission may allow ownership of two VHF television stations in the same market under certain circumstances if it does not harm competition or media diversity. SEC. 3. CROSS-OWNERSHIP LIMITATIONS. The Federal Communications Commission is required to make rule changes to eliminate restrictions on granting broadcast station licenses based on ownership of a daily newspaper and to remove the one-to-a-market rule. Additionally, minority voting stock interests will not be considered a cognizable interest if one holder owns more than 50% of the voting stock. Cable cross-ownership limitations under the Communications Act of 1934 are also amended. The Federal Communications Commission is amending cable cross-ownership limitations and dual-network rules to allow ownership interests in broadcasting stations and cable systems serving the same community. The Federal Communications Commission is amending cable cross-ownership limitations and dual-network rules to allow ownership interests in broadcasting stations and cable systems serving the same community. The FCC must complete all necessary actions within 90 days after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4 amends the Telecommunications Act of 1996 to increase the ownership limit from 35% to 45%. The Federal Communications Commission has 90 days to implement this change without revising certain regulations. SEC. 5 addresses reciprocal treatment of foreign ownership restrictions. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses, aeronautical radio stations, and corporations with significant foreign ownership. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast or common carrier licenses, aeronautical radio stations, and corporations with significant foreign ownership. The amendment includes provisions for corporations controlled by foreign entities and reciprocal treatment for broadcast station licenses in foreign countries. The Communications Act of 1934 is amended to restrict foreign ownership of broadcast licenses. If a foreign government allows US ownership of broadcast licenses, the FCC must allow foreign ownership of a portion of the capital stock of US corporations seeking or holding broadcast licenses. The FCC must allow foreign ownership of a portion of the capital stock of US corporations holding broadcast licenses, with a voting stock limit of 40 percent. The term 'United States person' includes corporations organized under US laws, US citizen individuals, US government entities, and their representatives. The term 'United States person' includes US citizens, US government entities, and their representatives.
